entries.name: Characters from Tletepec
entries: Si les joueurs veulent créer des personnages de Tletepec, pensez à leur poser les questions suivantes pendant la création du personnage :
{@b What offerings have you made to gods?} Avez-vous regretté la perte de votre offrande ? Avez-vous reçu la bénédiction que vous recherchiez ? Vous y attendiez-vous ou non ?
{@b Have you had to flee a natural disaster?} Que s'est-il passé ? Avez-vous perdu quelque chose en fuyant ? Qu'est-il arrivé à vos amis et à votre famille ?
{@b Have you trained with the Watchers of the Ashes} ? Cherchez-vous des présages dans la fumée ou les catastrophes ? Cherchez-vous des preuves d'un malheur à venir ?

entries.name: Tlexolotl
entries: Les tlexolotls sont de gigantesques créatures ressemblant à des salamandres qui sommeillent dans les profondeurs du magma des volcans endormis. Un tlexolotl somnole dans les profondeurs en fusion pendant des siècles, ne se levant que rarement pour se gorger de quantités massives de vie animale et végétale avant de retourner à son sommeil. Si le sommeil d'un tlexolotl est perturbé, que ce soit par des intrus dans sa tanière volcanique ou par l'éruption de son foyer en fusion, la brute baignée de lave émerge en furie, se déchaînant jusqu'à ce que son ventre soit plein et que son volcan soit à nouveau calme.

Malgré les prouesses destructrices du tlexolotl, la terre autour de son volcan est souvent naturellement abondante. Il est courant que ceux qui vivent à proximité honorent le tlexolotl en tant que protecteur de la terre, car les cendres qu'il crée rajeunissent le sol et encouragent la vie à s'épanouir.

data.name: In the Mists of Manivarsha
entries: {@i An Adventure for 9th-Level Characters}

Le dernier jour des épreuves de Shankha se déroule dans la ville de Sagorpur. Mais la joie de cette compétition des plus prometteuses se transforme en terreur lorsque le grand fleuve de la ville se gonfle d'une vague destructrice, emportant à la fois le champion des épreuves et le trophée sacré. Les personnages se joignent à l'effort pour sauver ceux qui sont perdus et rechercher une ancienne corruption qui est revenue.

entries.name: Background
entries: Shankhabhumi est un marécage boisé où trois grandes cités-états prospèrent sur un sol solide créé par les grâces des riverines, des gardiens spirituels sapiens. Chaque riverine est l'esprit patron d'une rivière, qui partage le nom de son patron. Les riverines des quatre plus grandes rivières de ce pays - l'Iravati, la Mehul, la Joltara et l'Adirohit, aujourd'hui disparue - ont élevé les îles sur lesquelles se trouvent les grandes villes. En échange, les habitants de Shankhabhumi rendent hommage aux capricieuses rivières par le biais des essais de Shankha.

Il y avait à l'origine quatre villes dans le Shankhabhumi, mais la ville de Manivarsha a été détruite pendant les épreuves de Shankha il y a cinq cents ans. La rivière protectrice de Manivarsha, Adirohit, a disparu, et sa rivière s'est réduite à des dizaines de ruisseaux marécageux. Les citoyens de Manivarshi qui étaient loin de chez eux ont été forcés d'adopter de nouvelles vies dans les trois autres villes, mais le souvenir de la ville perdue de Manivarsha demeure.

Aucune autre catastrophe ne s'est produite pendant des siècles. Mais aujourd'hui, la conclusion des plus récentes épreuves de Shankha a attiré l'attention d'un sinistre personnage du passé de Shankhabhumi. Il s'agit de l'ancien athlète {@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC}, une âme malfaisante dont le désir d'honneur éternel a directement causé la destruction de Manivarsha. Ayant vécu une vie maudite de monstre obsédé par l'orgueil dans les profondeurs des marais pendant des siècles, Jijibisha a récemment entendu parler d'un rival qui menace de revendiquer son titre de plus grand athlète Manivarshi de tous les temps. Ses illusions insultées, Jijibisha se prépare à utiliser le pouvoir d'un riverain piégé pour revendiquer à la fois l'honneur et la vie du champion de cette année.

entries.name: Pronunciations
entries: Le tableau des prononciations du Shankhabhumi indique comment prononcer les noms clés de cette aventure.

entries.name: Setting the Adventure
entries: Utilisez les suggestions suivantes pour aider à contextualiser le Shankhabhumi dans un monde plus large :

items.name: Through the Radiant Citadel
items.entry: Les personnages voyageant depuis la Citadelle Radieuse arrivent juste à la sortie de Sagorpur. Si vous souhaitez détailler davantage cette région, utilisez la section "{@area Shankhabhumi Gazetteer|2d2|x}" à la fin de cette aventure comme point de départ.

items.name: Eberron
items.entry: Shankhabhumi pourrait apparaître comme sa propre île entre les continents de Khorvaire et de Xen'drik. Il pourrait également s'agir d'une nation cachée dans Xen'drik, à l'est du Lac de la Terreur.

items.name: Forgotten Realms
items.entry: On peut trouver Shankhabhumi dans les jungles au sud de la mer brillante, près de Chult, ou sur sa propre île à l'ouest de Lantan.

entries.name: Character Hooks
entries: Considérez les moyens suivants pour impliquer les personnages dans cette aventure :

items.name: Event Guards
items.entry: Les juges qui supervisent les épreuves de Shankha veulent s'assurer que cet événement important se déroule sans heurts. Ils engagent les personnages pour servir de gardes du corps aux athlètes visiteurs.

items.name: Holy Waters
items.entry: Les personnages ou leurs alliés ont besoin d'un réactif magique ou d'eau bénie et pensent que les riverains de Shankhabhumi peuvent les fournir. Cependant, lorsque les personnages arrivent à Sagorpur, la ville est plongée dans les derniers jours des épreuves de Shankha. Les membres du temple riverain local ne fourniront ces eaux qu'après la fin de l'agitation qui entoure les épreuves.

entries.name: The Shankha Trials
entries: Les personnages qui viennent à Shankhabhumi apprennent les détails suivants sur un événement passionnant appelé les épreuves de Shankha :

items: Les épreuves de Shankha sont un spectacle d'art et d'athlétisme. Elles tirent leur nom des coquilles de shankha - coquilles de mollusques conques - qui figurent dans les légendes de Shankhabhumi et sont une icône du pays.
Ces concours se déroulent sur une période de douze jours tous les douze ans.
Les concurrents viennent des trois cités-états de Shankhabhumi, dont certains descendent des survivants de la ville en ruines de Manivarsha.
Les concours comprennent la construction de bateaux, la course de bateaux, la cuisine, la danse, la plongée shankha et la natation.
Les concours honorent les riverines de la région, des esprits qui détiennent le pouvoir sur les nombreuses rivières de la région.

Un candidat parmi trois douzaines d'autres sort vainqueur et remporte le grand trophée en forme de coquille de conque connu sous le nom de Shankha des riverains, qui ornera sa ville jusqu'à la prochaine compétition.

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries.title: A devastating wave from the Iravati River crashes upon the Riverine Temple in Sagorpur

entries: L'aventure commence alors que les personnages se trouvent dans la ville de Sagorpur pour la fin de la compétition appelée les épreuves de Shankha. Utilisez la section "{@area Character Hooks|2a2|x}" pour déterminer pourquoi les personnages se retrouvent dans la ville, et la section "{@area Shankhabhumi Gazetteer|2d2|x}" à la fin de cette aventure pour détailler davantage la ville. Lisez ou paraphrasez ce qui suit lorsque vous êtes prêt à commencer :

La ville de Sagorpur regorge de spectateurs qui profitent des épreuves de Shankha. L'épreuve finale de cette grande compétition se déroule près du temple de la rivière Iravati, un ancien édifice d'argile brûlée orné d'images de lys et d'esprits qui se cachent derrière la mousse et les vignes. D'innombrables spectateurs remplissent les rues environnantes et bordent la rivière.

Si les personnages ne connaissent pas encore les informations de la section "{@area The Shankha Trials|2a3|x}", c'est le moment idéal pour qu'ils les apprennent. Cela peut être raconté par un allié amical ou des habitants enthousiastes dans la foule.

La foule s'est rassemblée pour l'événement final des épreuves de Shankha, où un jeune prodige populaire - la danseuse Amanisha Manivarshi, appelée Nisha par ses fans - est sur le point de se produire. Son nom passe à travers la foule avec un bourdonnement d'excitation. Les personnages ont une vision claire de sa performance. Lisez la description suivante pour ceux qui regardent :

La performance d'Amanisha est à couper le souffle, mais elle est empreinte de tristesse. Pendant qu'elle danse, un présentateur explique que sa performance représente l'histoire de la destruction mystérieuse de la ville de Manivarsha et de l'angoisse portée par Nisha et tous les Manivarshi qui ne retourneront jamais sur leur terre ancestrale. À la fin de la danse, une acclamation tumultueuse s'élève de la foule.

Un personnage qui réussit un test de Sagesse ({@skill Insight}) ou de Charisme ({@skill Performance}) DC 10 réalise que la danse de Nisha était exceptionnelle et a capturé quelque chose de significatif pour de nombreuses personnes dans la foule. Certains spectateurs essuient le bord de leurs yeux.

Après de brèves délibérations, les juges présentent un grand trophée en forme de conque, le Shankha de Riverine. Un juge s'incline, puis fait signe à Nisha de s'avancer. Au milieu des acclamations et de la fanfare, elle accepte le trophée et prend sa place en tant que nouvelle championne des épreuves de Shankha.

entries.name: Storm of Destruction
entries: Alors que Nisha élève la Shankha de la Riverine au-dessus de sa tête et que les épreuves de Shankha se terminent, lisez la description suivante :

Le tonnerre gronde et le ciel se remplit de nuages. De la rivière autrefois calme, une vague s'élève, formant une énorme vague qui projette les bateaux sur les rives. La vague massive se transforme en une puissante houle qui s'abat sur le rivage bondé et le temple fluvial.

Les personnages ont un moment pour réagir à la catastrophe soudaine. La place qui entoure le temple fluvial fait des milliers de mètres de long et est bondée de monde. Les personnages ne peuvent pas faire grand-chose pour arrêter la vague soudaine, mais une réflexion rapide ou la magie - comme la téléportation au sommet des bâtiments environnants ou un sort au moment précis {@spell control water} - pourrait épargner les personnages et ceux qui les entourent.

Lorsque la vague s'écrase sur la place, chaque personnage doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de Force DC 15. Ceux qui échouent subissent 9 ({@dice 2d8}) dégâts de matraquage et sont assommés {@condition prone}. Ceux qui réussissent subissent la moitié des dégâts et ne sont pas assommés {@condition prone}. Ces dégâts sont moindres dans les autres parties de la grande place mais provoquent le chaos dans l'espace ouvert, brisant les étals des vendeurs, blessant des centaines de personnes et laissant derrière eux un pied d'eau stagnante qui transforme la zone en {@book difficult terrain|PHB|8|Difficult Terrain}.

entries.name: Mass Destruction
entries: La vague a causé une dévastation totale sur la place, et des centaines de personnes se précipitent pour s'échapper. Faites un ou plusieurs jets sur la table de chaos des vagues pour voir quels périls attendent les personnages.

entries.caption: Wave Chaos
rows: Un étalage vendant des boissons à la mangue s'est effondré. Un personnage doit réussir un test de Force ({@skill Athletics}) DC 14 pour libérer les vendeurs pris au piège.
Un habitant trop serviable essaie avec insistance d'amener le personnage le plus frêle à fuir avec lui.
Un aîné est tombé. Il est meurtri et séparé de sa famille. Un personnage doit réussir un test de Sagesse ({@skill Perception}) DC 16 pour retrouver la famille perdue au milieu du chaos.

Un local désespéré qui cherche par terre les 20 sp qu'il a perdus dans la vague risque d'être piétiné par ceux qui fuient. Un personnage peut amener l'habitant à cesser ses recherches et à se mettre en sécurité en remplaçant les pièces d'argent perdues ou en réussissant un test de Charisme DC 14 ({@skill Intimidation} ou {@skill Persuasion}).
Les débris à la dérive se fracassent sur les personnages au sol, chacun devant réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Dextérité DC 14 ou être renversé {@condition prone}.
La vague lave un hostile {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes} dans la foule proche.

entries.name: Chaos at the Temple
entries: Après quelques rounds de lutte contre la destruction, le personnage qui a le plus haut score de Sagesse passive ({@skill Perception}) voit la scène suivante :
Au pied du temple, des créatures d'eau vive attaquent les personnes qui tentent de fuir.
Un hostile {@creature water elemental} et deux {@creature Water Weird||water weirds} à la tête en forme de cobras royaux attaquent quiconque s'approche du temple.

Un personnage qui réussit un test d'Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) DC 14 réalise que les créatures aquatiques sont des défenseurs du temple. Un personnage qui utilise une action et réussit un test de Charisme ({@skill Intimidation} ou {@skill Persuasion}) DC 16 convainc les créatures confuses de se retirer ; les élémentaires se dissolvent alors à nouveau dans les eaux du temple.

entries.name: Survivors at the Temple
entries: Une fois les gardiens du temple éliminés, plusieurs personnes émergent de l'intérieur du temple. Il s'agit des participants et des juges des épreuves de Shankha, dont le chef du temple, le Haut Rôdeur Plabon Bhatiyali-un halfling de 200 ans, bon chaotique {@creature priest}. Beaucoup sont blessés, mais heureusement tout le monde est vivant. Cependant, Amanisha Manivarshi et le trophée Shankha de la Riverine ont disparu. Plabon s'approche des personnages, et il dit :

"La rivière est venue pour Amanisha et la Shankha de Riverine. Le mur d'eau est descendu et a coulé autour de nous, cherchant Amanisha alors qu'elle essayait d'aider les autres à se mettre en sécurité. Il s'est emparé d'elle et du trophée, puis les a éloignés tous les deux !"

entries.name: The Riversinger's Fears
entries: Plabon est peu loquace mais insiste pour partager ce dont il a été témoin avec les personnages. Utilisez les points suivants pour guider la conversation :

items: Plabon est l'un des juges des procès de Shankha.
Bien que les riverains détiennent le pouvoir de contrôler l'eau de la rivière, Plabon ne croit pas que cette catastrophe soit le fait d'Iravati, l'esprit de la rivière de Sagorpur.
Plabon a ressenti une profonde jalousie dans la tempête et la rivière. Il craint que la destruction d'aujourd'hui soit liée à la catastrophe qui s'est abattue sur la ville de Manivarsha.
Les récits de la ruine de Manivarsha parlent d'une tempête soudaine et d'une énorme vague qui s'est élevée au-dessus de la forêt marécageuse, puis a consumé la ville.
Il pense qu'Amanisha est la clé pour comprendre ce qui s'est passé et veut que les personnages la trouvent.

entries: Plabon offre aux personnages 400 gp chacun s'ils trouvent et ramènent Amanisha. Si les personnages rechignent, d'autres juges - des habitants influents et des sénateurs de la ville - ajoutent à la récompense, la portant à 500 gp chacun en trésors et en biens commerciaux, ainsi que 20 acres de terres agricoles fertiles en dehors de la ville.

Si les personnages acceptent, Plabon admet que la tâche ne sera pas facile ; les forêts marécageuses inondées du Shankhabhumi sont vastes. Il encourage les personnages à trouver un bateau et un guide qui puisse les emmener en amont de la rivière à la recherche d'Amanisha.
Avant que les personnages ne partent, Plabon donne à l'un d'entre eux un petit coquillage shankha provenant du temple. Ce coquillage fonctionne comme un {@item stone of good luck}.

entries.name: Venturing from Sagorpur
entries: Les forêts marécageuses du Shankhabhumi défient toute tentative de cartographie. Les voyageurs le long des rivières doivent compter sur des navigateurs expérimentés pour les guider. Alors que les personnages se préparent à remonter la rivière pour trouver Amanisha, ils apprennent que de nombreuses embarcations de la ville ont été endommagées par la vague désastreuse. Même s'ils ont leur propre bateau, ils devront engager un navigateur pour celui-ci.

Les personnages qui cherchent le long du bord de la rivière trouvent les bateaux fluviaux de la ville en désordre après la catastrophe. Cependant, alors qu'ils cherchent, un bateau s'arrête dans le port. C'est le navire d'un majhi-ou navigateur expérimenté, nommé Dukha Majhi Sagorpuri. Il vient juste d'arriver dans la ville.

entries.name: Dukha Bhatiyali
entries: Dukha Bhatiyali est un majhi expérimenté. Bien qu'il semble humain, ses collègues et ses passagers ne savent pas qu'il est un {@creature weretiger} (neutre). Alors que plusieurs bandes de lycanthropes de ce type vivent au fond des forêts marécageuses de Shankhabhumi, Dukha a quitté sa tribu et tente de vivre comme un humain. Il parcourt les rivières autour de Sagorpur sous une apparence humaine et soumet tous ceux qui l'accompagnent dans ses expéditions à des récits interminables sur les traditions de la forêt.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: "Je sais tout ce qu'il y a à savoir sur les forêts marécageuses !"

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "En dehors des villes, la terre doit être tenue en harmonie entre les gens et les riverains."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "Je protégerai le territoire de mon peuple, mais je veux vivre selon mes propres conditions."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "Je vois du danger partout."

entries.name: Way of the Waters
entries: Si les personnages cherchent à engager Dukha, il propose de les guider pour 100 gp. Un personnage qui marchande et réussit un test de Charisme ({@skill Persuasion}) DC 14 le convainc de réduire ce prix de 25 gp. Une fois l'accord conclu, il partage ces détails :

items: Dukha se dirigeait vers Sagorpur quand la vague a frappé.

En s'approchant, il a vu un courant d'eau scintiller d'une étrange lumière verte et s'éloigner de la ville. Il a vu cette même ondulation lumineuse récemment le long des affluents locaux de la rivière Iravati. La première fois qu'il l'a vue, c'était il y a douze jours, le premier jour des épreuves de Shankha.
Il a suivi les ondulations lumineuses, les traçant le long d'une petite rivière appelée la Tinjhorna.
Près d'une série de chutes d'eau, Tinjhorna le riverain a averti Dukha de rester à l'écart, accusant les mortels de libérer de la magie corrompue sur ses eaux.
Dukha peut partager tous les détails dans la section "{@area Riverine|2e2|x}" à la fin de cette aventure.

entries: Dukha propose d'emmener les personnages à cette même série de chutes d'eau sur la rivière Tinjhorna dans l'espoir d'en apprendre plus sur les riverains. Il n'a guère d'autres informations et, pour l'instant, il ne partage pas le fait qu'il est un tigre-garou.

Le bateau de Doukha est un skiff étroit, à fond plat, avec de la place pour les personnages mais peu d'autres choses. Il se déplace à une vitesse de 1½ miles par heure. Le majhi est prêt à partir quand les personnages le souhaitent.

entries.name: Contacting the Riverine Iravati
entries: Les personnages peuvent tenter de contacter Iravati, la gardienne riveraine de la rivière qui coule à Sagorpur. La riverine, comme la rivière, est apathique et lente à agir. Aucun appel ou offrande fait à Iravati ne provoque l'apparition de la riverine.

entries.name: The Swamp Forest
entries: Dukha pilote son esquif jusqu'à l'embouchure de la rivière Tinjhorna, un voyage qui prend 10 heures dans son bateau. De là, le voyage vers les chutes d'eau prend 10 heures supplémentaires. Le voyage à travers la forêt marécageuse se déroule sans encombre jusqu'à ce que le bateau atteigne les voies d'eau plus sauvages et plus étroites de la rivière Tinjhorna. Toutes les 3 heures que les personnages passent à voyager sur la rivière Tinjhorna, ou quand vous le souhaitez, lancez un dé sur la table des Rencontres du voyage en rivière pour voir ce qui se passe.

entries.caption: River Journey Encounters
rows: Il pleut abondamment. Pendant l'heure qui suit, le bateau et ses environs sont {@book heavily obscured|PHB|8|Vision and Light}. Faites un nouveau lancer sur cette table, en ignorant tout autre résultat de 1 ou 2.

Le courant augmente le long d'une partie étroite de la rivière. Dukha demande instamment aux personnages de l'aider à ramer vers l'amont. Tous les personnages doivent réussir un test de Force ({@skill Athletics}) DC 10. Le bateau perd une demi-heure de progression pour chaque test raté ou pour chaque personnage qui n'aide pas.

Un {@creature treant} en forme de mangrove bloque le chemin vers l'avant. Le tréant ne se déplace que si le groupe écoute son ode d'une heure au marais, ou si un personnage réussit un test de Charisme ({@skill Persuasion}) DC 18 pour le convaincre de laisser passer le skiff.

Un {@creature spirit naga} apparaît et demande où vont les personnages. Il propose à un seul personnage de lui donner son trésor magique, un {@item pearl of power}, si celui-ci est assez courageux pour le laisser le mordre trois fois.

Six esprits des marais (utilisez le bloc de stat {@creature mud mephit}) émergent de la rivière, exigeant que les personnages leur remettent leurs objets de valeur les plus brillants. Ils peuvent être chassés par la force ou en réussissant un test de Charisme ({@skill Intimidation}) DC 14.

entries.name: Falls Clearing
entries: Lorsque les personnages s'approchent de la série de chutes d'eau, lisez la description suivante :

Un grondement croissant étouffe les bruits de la forêt tropicale bien avant que la rivière ne tourne, révélant une série de chutes d'eau parallèles tombant d'une crête qui longe la rivière. Un chapelet d'îles aux forêts clairsemées se trouve sur la rive opposée de la rivière, à la base des chutes.

Dukha explique que c'est là qu'il a rencontré le Tinjhorna riverain. Il amarre le bateau au milieu des îles en face des chutes pour que le groupe puisse tenter d'invoquer la rivière - et pour le garder en sécurité au cas où l'esprit s'avérerait hostile.

Alors que Dukha attache le bateau, les personnages qui réussissent un test de Sagesse ({@skill Perception}) DC 14 remarquent plusieurs paires d'yeux verts et félins qui les observent depuis le feuillage de l'île. Lorsqu'ils sont remarqués ou peu après que les personnages aient atterri sur l'île, trois hostiles {@creature Weretiger||weretigers} sous forme hybride émergent avec des arcs longs tirés. Ils jaugent les intentions du groupe pendant 1 round avant d'attaquer. Un personnage qui parle aux tigres-garous pendant ce round peut les convaincre de ne pas attaquer en réussissant un test de Charisme ({@skill Intimidation} ou {@skill Persuasion}) DC 16. Même si les tigres-garous attaquent, un personnage qui dépense une action peut tenter ce test, convainquant les tigres-garous de se retirer en cas de réussite. Tous les tigres-garous fuient le combat lorsque l'un d'entre eux est réduit à 10 points de vie ou moins.

entries.name: Dukha's Role
entries: Dukha essaie de rester à l'écart de ce conflit, mais il ne veut pas voir ses compagnons tigres-garous blessés. Si les tigres-garous attaquent, Dukha crie aux lycanthropes de se retirer, en leur disant que les personnages viennent en paix. Si le combat dure plus de 2 rounds, Dukha se transforme en forme hybride et se bat aux côtés des personnages jusqu'à ce que les autres tigres-garous soient chassés. S'il le fait, il en veut aux personnages pour leur manque de diplomatie et ne les aidera pas dans les combats futurs. Cependant, s'il n'a pas à le faire, il apprécie le respect des personnages pour les créatures de la forêt et aide le groupe dans tous les conflits futurs où ils auront besoin d'aide.

entries.name: Tiger Talk
entries: Si les personnages conversent avec les tigres-garous, ou s'ils les font fuir et interrogent ensuite Dukha, il devient clair que Dukha et les tigres-garous se connaissent. Dukha ou les tigres-garous partagent les informations suivantes :

items: Cette zone est le territoire des tigres-garous, et ils ont remarqué des changements anormaux dans le débit de la rivière.
Les tigres-garous pensent que les habitants de Sagorpur ont causé le dérangement.
Ils cherchent à protéger leur territoire de toute personne qui pourrait lui nuire ou nuire à la Tinjhorna riveraine.
Les tigres-garous n'ont pas vu le riverain Tinjhorna depuis qu'il a affronté Dukha, mais le riverain fréquente souvent le bassin en haut des chutes.
Si ce n'est déjà fait, Dukha révèle qu'il est un lycanthrope et qu'il a été élevé parmi les tigres-garous qui vivent dans la forêt.

entries: Après avoir discuté avec les personnages, les tigres-garous encouragent le groupe à ne pas s'attarder sur leur territoire, puis ils partent. Dukha ne s'excuse pas d'avoir caché sa vraie nature et encourage les personnages à poursuivre leur recherche du Tinjhorna riverain au sommet des chutes.

entries.name: Headwater Pool
entries: De l'endroit où Dukha amarre son bateau, les personnages peuvent suivre un chemin indirect mais généralement sec jusqu'aux falaises où les cascades parallèles tombent en cascade. Pour escalader la paroi rocheuse glissante de 20 pieds de haut autour des cascades, il faut réussir un test de Force ({@skill Athletics}) DC 12. Ceux qui échouent tombent de 3 mètres dans l'eau. Si plus d'un personnage tombe, un {@creature swarm of quippers} le remarque et attaque.
Lorsque le premier personnage atteint le sommet des chutes d'eau, la scène suivante se déroule devant lui :

Les chutes d'eau adjacentes sont alimentées par un large bassin peu profond entouré de mangroves anciennes. À vingt pieds de là, un jeune homme à la peau verte marche sur l'eau, parlant doucement tout en tournant lentement autour de deux piliers d'écume verte rougeoyante.

Tinjhorna le {@creature riverine|JttRC} (détaillé au {@area end of this adventure|2e2|x}) parle en aquan et tente de calmer une paire de {@creature Water Elemental||water elementals} corrompus par l'étrange magie qui afflige sa rivière.

Les personnages qui réussissent un test d'Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) DC 12 reconnaissent les piliers écumants comme des élémentaires d'eau. Les personnages risquent de provoquer les élémentaires s'ils sont bruyants ou s'approchent sans précaution. Les personnages qui s'approchent prudemment et réussissent un test DC 15 d'Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) ou de Charisme ({@skill Persuasion}) pour calmer les créatures aident Tinjhorna à apaiser les élémentaires, et un instant plus tard, les créatures disparaissent. Si les personnages sont agressifs, les élémentaires d'eau sont effrayés et attaquent.
La piscine a une profondeur de 4 pieds et est {@book difficult terrain|PHB|8|Difficult Terrain}.

entries.name: Speaking with Tinjhorna
entries: Tinjhorna est un jeune riverain neutre qui apparaît comme un jeune homme à la voix douce et aux cheveux longs. Sa rivière est l'un des nombreux cours d'eau créés lors des retombées géologiques après la destruction de la ville de Manivarsha et du grand fleuve Adirohit. Bien qu'il rêve de devenir un jour un fleuve puissant, son rêve est mis en péril par l'étrange magie qui infecte ses eaux.
Tinjhorna remercie les personnages pour leur aide et converse avec eux avec empressement. Utilisez les points suivants pour guider la conversation :

items: Il y a une semaine environ, Tinjhorna a senti une ancienne puissance affecter sa rivière, comme si quelque chose se déplaçait dans les eaux vers le sud-ouest.
Il n'y a pas grand-chose dans cette direction, sauf une zone hantée appelée la Forêt des Mains.
La Forêt des Mains occupe en grande partie les mêmes terres que la rivière Adirohit disparue et la ville disparue de Manivarsha.
La magie que Tinjhorna a ressentie a provoqué la colère de nombreux habitants de la forêt marécageuse environnante. Il est très occupé à essayer de les calmer.
Tinjhorna n'a vu aucune trace de la danseuse perdue Amanisha, mais il demande aux personnages de chercher la source de la magie qui affecte sa rivière.

entries: Si les personnages acceptent d'aider le riverain, il les remercie et leur donne un {@item Potion of Superior Healing||potion of healing (superior)}. Le riverain propose de veiller sur les personnages s'ils souhaitent se reposer près des chutes mais ne voyagera pas avec eux, car il doit s'occuper des créatures dérangées le long de sa rivière.

entries.name: Forest of Hands
entries: Depuis les chutes d'eau, le voyage vers la Forêt des Mains prend 10 heures. Dukha continue de servir de navigateur aux personnages, quels que soient les événements survenus à la cascade. Toutes les 3 heures que les personnages passent à voyager sur la rivière Tinjhorna, ou quand vous le souhaitez, lancez un dé sur le {@adventure River Journey Encounters table|JttRC|9|River Journey Encounters} de la section "{@area The Swamp Forest|2b8|x}".
Lorsque les personnages atteignent la Forêt des Mains, lisez la description suivante :

L'odeur du marais a la douce puanteur de la chair en décomposition. Des arbres aux membres tombants se dressent au milieu de la rivière, leurs branches ressemblant à des centaines de mains grises et leurs feuilles pendantes à de longs doigts de cuir.

Les personnages qui réussissent un test d'Intelligence DC 14 ({@skill History} ou {@skill Nature}) reconnaissent les fameux arbres angul de la région, des plantes qui puent la chair pourrie et dégagent une sève cramoisie. Ces arbres sont inoffensifs, mais de nombreux voyageurs trouvent les longues feuilles en forme de doigts qui glissent sur eux lorsqu'ils passent en dessous plus que déconcertantes.

entries.title: The swamp forests of Shankhabhumi hold equal measure of beauty and danger

entries: Le voyage à travers la Forêt des Mains dure 3 heures. Faites un jet ou choisissez une rencontre sur la table des rencontres de la forêt des mains après chaque heure de voyage.

entries.caption: Forest of Hands Encounters
rows: Trois caillots de sève d'angul animé (utiliser le bloc de stat {@creature black pudding}) attaquent depuis l'eau.

Des bateaux spectraux apparaissent à travers les arbres. Dukha ou un personnage qui réussit un test d'Intelligence ({@skill History}) DC 14 sait que ces fantômes sont des voyageurs qui se sont perdus lors de la ruine de Manivarsha. Les esprits sont troublants mais inoffensifs.

Le brouillard se lève et {@book lightly obscures|PHB|8|Vision and Light} la forêt. À travers elle, deux {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o-wisps} tentent d'entraîner les personnages sur le chemin d'un {@creature hydra} hostile.
Un ermite {@creature fomorian} bloque le passage du bateau. Il exige que les personnages lui préparent un repas, sinon il les mangera. Il n'aime que la nourriture dégoûtante.

entries.name: Forest Heart
entries: En avançant dans la Forêt des Mains, les personnages finissent par atteindre une clairière au cœur de la forêt. Cette zone est représentée sur la carte 9.1. Lisez la description suivante lorsque les personnages arrivent :

Plusieurs cours d'eau lents se rejoignent sur une île rocheuse couverte de mousse et de pierres en ruine. Au sommet se trouve la souche noircie et pourrie d'un grand arbre. Sur cette souche, Amanisha Manivarshi est allongée, immobile.

L'eau dans cette zone a une profondeur de 10 pieds (voir le {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} pour les détails sur {@book swimming|PHB|8|Climbing, Swimming, and Crawling}). L'île s'élève doucement au nord et au sud, tandis que sur ses côtés est et ouest, des falaises de 10 pieds de haut s'élèvent de la rivière. Les personnages qui réussissent un test de Sagesse ({@skill Perception}) DC 18 remarquent que les rochers de l'île ressemblent aux pièces d'une structure ancienne.

Amanisha (neutre bonne, humaine {@creature spy}) est {@condition unconscious}. Elle n'a actuellement aucune arme et 5 points de vie. Une guérison magique ou un test de Sagesse ({@skill Medicine}) réussi à DC 20 la ramène à la conscience. Les personnages qui cherchent son trophée des épreuves de Shankha, le Shankha de Riverine, ne le voient pas.

entries.name: Amanisha Manivarshi
entries: Amanisha Manivarshi is an accomplished dancer and the most recent champion of the Shankha Trials. Known as Nisha to her friends and fans, she is a charming young woman whose Manivarshi ancestors settled in Tippurika after their home disappeared. Nisha uses the last name "Manivarshi" out of respect for her family and heritage.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: "Many see my focus and assume I'm not approachable. But I welcome new friends."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I will make the city of my birth and descendants of Manivarsha proud by bringing home the Riverine's Shankha."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "The folk of the Manivarshi diaspora cling too much to memories. I will give them something new to celebrate."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I am both a child of Tippurika and a descendant of Manivarsha. I am quick to hold a grudge against those who tell me I have to be one or the other."

entries.name: Prisoner of the Past
entries: Nisha awakens in a fog, confused and disoriented. She calms down if the characters assure her that they've come to help. Nisha shares the following information:

items: The wave that smashed Sagorpur seized Nisha and the Riverine's Shankha, then dragged them here.

Once here, Nisha was attacked by a monstrous woman with gray skin that oozes crimson ichor, like the surrounding forest's angul trees. The fiend seized the Riverine's Shankha, declaring it belonged to her.
The fiend claimed this place marks the edge of the ruins of lost Manivarsha.
The fiend said that if Nisha thinks she's Manivarshi, then she can be a prisoner here for the rest of her days.

entries.name: Jijibisha's Vengeance
entries: {@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC}, a vicious soul from the land's past, lurks in the nearby forest. Long ago she made a deal with wicked otherworldly forces that gave her longevity and fiendish powers, a bargain that ultimately resulted in the ruin of Manivarsha. She is behind Amanisha's capture and is loath to let her prisoner escape.

Before the party can complete their conversation with Amanisha, the effects of Jijibisha's {@spell wall of fire} spell spring up, separating as many characters from their boat as possible. Read the following description:
A woman with tattered, ancient robes and skin the color of a drowned corpse walks out of swamp at the south edge of the island.

"Welcome, visitors! I am {@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC}—I'm sure you've heard of me. I know you've come to steal my trophy," the woman says, holding up the Riverine's Shankha. "But I am the last champion of Manivarshi to win the Riverine's Shankha—not this upstart. It cost me everything, but my victory is eternal!"

{@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC} uses the {@creature ultroloth} stat block, but she has access to only the {@spell wall of fire} spell and the at-will spells from her Innate Spellcasting trait. Despite her fiendish powers, she looks like an ancient, withered human.

After she finishes speaking, Jijibisha attacks. She attempts to use her Hypnotic Gaze to turn Dukha and Amanisha against the characters. While she fights, Jijibisha mocks the characters, claiming to be the last champion of Manivarsha and the only Manivarshi who can rightfully claim the Riverine's Shankha. If Jijibisha is separated from the Riverine's Shankha, she has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls until she regains it. She fights to the death.

A character who succeeds on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check has heard of {@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC} and can confirm that she was favored to win the Shankha Trials the year Manivarsha was destroyed.

entries.name: Adirohit's Retribution
entries: When {@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC} is destroyed, all is silent for a moment before a voice drifts from beneath the tree stump at the center of the Forest Heart.
"You out there!" calls a voice from beneath the tree stump. "Has that horror been banished? Is she finally gone? Set things right. Set me free!"
If the characters respond to the voice, the speaker shares the following information:

items: The voice says he is Adirohit, the riverine of the lost Adirohit River, which once nourished the great city of Manivarsha.

Adirohit has been locked away for hundreds of years beneath a mighty mangrove that once adorned a temple built in his honor—ever since the Shankha Trials that precipitated the destruction of Manivarsha.
Jijibisha trapped him here using her fiendish power and forced him to cause the flood in Sagorpur.
Now that Jijibisha is gone, touching any blessed shankha to the tree stump will release him.

entries: Using either the Riverine's Shankha or the magical shankha Plabon gifted the characters releases Adirohit. However, Amanisha urges the characters to consider cautiously.
Through roleplaying or by succeeding on a DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, a character can convince Adirohit to reveal the following details:

items: Long ago, {@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC} made a deal with a wicked god to give her fiendish powers that would ensure her victory in the Shankha Trials.
Adirohit was outraged that humans would pervert the sacred trials and unleashed a flood to punish the whole city by sinking it into the swamp.
{@creature Jijibisha Manivarshi|JttRC} survived, though, and declared herself winner of the trials.
Jijibisha used her sinister powers to bind Adirohit within his ruined temple.
Jijibisha was delighted that she would be the last Manivarshi to ever win the Shankha Trials—at least, until Amanisha's victory.

entries: While Adirohit is a captive now and has been used by Jijibisha, he was not when he sank Manivarsha.

It's up to the characters to determine whether or not they free Adirohit. Amanisha has complex feelings about this, seeing Adirohit as a tie to her ancient people and one who could restore a measure of what was lost, but also a tempestuous being who destroyed her ancestors. She will not impede the characters no matter what choice they make.

entries.name: Adirohit's Fate
entries: If the characters free Adirohit, he emerges from the stump in a torrent of river water. He is an arrogant, chaotic neutral {@creature riverine|JttRC} (detailed at the {@area end of this adventure|2e2|x}) who looks like a muscular, middle-aged man with white hair and blue skin. He thanks the characters for their service and brings forth treasure to reward them with (see the following section). Adirohit is unapologetic for his past deeds, even if Amanisha or others ask him to explain Manivarsha's fate. He's confident, though, that he can reestablish his river and that soon enough humans will build a new, greater city on its banks. He invites the characters to rest here under his protection and tell him how the world has changed. Amanisha has no interest in doing this, though—what Adirohit did to Manivarsha fills her with anger. Feel free to roleplaying the contentious dynamic between Amanisha and Adirohit, or encourage the characters to choose sides, as much as you please.
Ultimately, the riverine allows the characters to leave whenever they like but insists on rewarding them for freeing him before they do.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Using his magic, Adirohit causes the following treasures to rise upon a geyser from the ruins beneath the island, bequeathing them upon the characters:

items: A fist-sized sapphire worth 6,000 gp
An {@item Elemental Gem, Emerald||emerald elemental gem} that conjures a {@creature water elemental} that resembles Adirohit
An intricately carved jade statuette depicting a muscular version of Adirohit, worth 500 gp
A waterproof sack containing a length of the finest silk bastra, embroidered with pearls worth 250 gp

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: The journey back to the Tinjhorna River is uneventful. The riverine Tinjhorna is enthusiastic to hear about the characters' journey and thanks them for investigating. When the characters return to Sagorpur with Amanisha and the Riverine's Shankha, they receive a hero's welcome, along with the rewards Plabon and the other trial judges promised. Depending on Adirohit's fate, only time will tell how the riverine could change the waters of the swamp forest or whether he is lost forever.

entries.name: Shankhabhumi Gazetteer
entries: Shaped and defined by its rivers, Shankhabhumi is a dynamic floodplain surrounded by mountains and crisscrossed by waterways. Most of the land is covered in swamp forests infested with unknown perils, except for three city-states that stand proudly on broad islands of miraculously dry land. The islands on which the cities of Ashwadhatu, Sagorpur, and Tippurika stand were each granted to the people by a different riverine, and at the heart of each city is a temple dedicated to that city's patron riverine. A fourth city, Manivarsha, was destroyed in a cataclysm five hundred years ago.

Each city spreads out in concentric circles from its riverine temple. The innermost circle holds the city's senate house, main market, and academy, as well as the houses of wealthy citizens. Past these lie modest residential neighborhoods and trade wards. At its edges, each city slopes down to submerged rice fields before dissipating into the swamps. The skies of Shankhabhumi are eternally heavy with rainclouds, and even well-maintained buildings wear a fine coat of moss.

To experience Shankhabhumi at its finest, one must visit during the Shankha Trials, held every twelve years in one of the three cities. A twelve-day spectacle of skill and might, the trials feature contestants representing each city who entertain thousands of spectators. But the trials are more than a competition; they represent the origin story of the land and a pact endlessly renewed between the people and the riverines to whom the land belongs.

entries.name: Features
entries: Those familiar with Shankhabhumi know the following details:

items.name: Hallmarks
items.entry: This region is known for its isolated city-states separated by tangled swamps, and for the capricious river spirits that rule its waters.

items.name: People
items.entry: Urban society is a mix of humans, halflings, elves, and dwarves. Skin tones in Shankhabhumi span shades of brown, and people have uniformly dark hair that ranges from wavy to very curly.

items.name: Languages
items.entry: The folk of Shankhabhumi speak Common and Shankhi, the regional tongue.

entries.name: Noteworthy Sites
entries: Hundreds of rivers flow through Shankhabhumi, creating natural paths to its three great cities.

entries.name: Ashwadhatu
entries: The Mehul River flows from the Nirjhar Highlands, through Ashwadhatu, and on to Dishahara Bay. The city of Shankhabhumi with the largest area of solid land, Ashwadhatu has long been the home of proud, traditionalist farmers, miners, and boatbuilders. More recently, metalworkers and inventors are fueling a growing industry, though some citizens dismiss them as eccentrics creating unnecessary, newfangled contrivances.

entries.name: Sagorpur
entries: Sagorpur is the mightiest city of Shankhabhumi, having inherited that mantle when Manivarsha was ruined five centuries ago. The city lies where the Iravati River flows into Dishahara Bay, and its mainstay is sea trade. A wide array of goods can be purchased in the city's sprawling markets, and seafaring foreigners and inland travelers from Tippurika and Ashwadhatu mingle with locals in Sagorpur's numerous inns, playhouses, gambling dens, and restaurants.

entries.name: Tippurika
entries: The city of Tippurika stands where the Joltara River flows from the Adhameru Mountains into a deep canyon, frothing with whitewater rapids. Tippuri citizens—a majority of them dwarves and halflings—are adept at climbing steep paths, traversing unstable rope bridges, fishing in mountain rapids, and exploring the inaccessible caves of the mountains. The city is known for its hill crops—particularly tea and timber. Locals take pride in their staunch courage and infuriating stubbornness in equal measure.

entries.name: Life in Shankhabhumi
entries: Outsiders often refer to the people of Shankhabhumi collectively as "riverlanders," but the folk of the three city-states call themselves Sagorpuri, Ashwadhatuj, or Tippuri, and claim to have little in common with one another. However, that's an exaggeration; the people of Shankhabhumi share unifying traits and experiences.

entries.name: Clothing and Accoutrements
entries: The folk of Shankhabhumi favor clothing composed of lengths of cotton or silk cloth called bastras, which are wrapped around the body in various styles. These include the loose, voluminous drapes of a sedentary noble, the tight, ropelike wrap of a Shankha Trials contestant, and the practical, gathered garments of a laborer or river navigator.

Wavy or curly hair is common in the region; people rub it to a shine with coconut oil and wear it long or in thick plaits. Ornaments include conch-shell bangles and hairpieces, as well as designs of white clay painted directly onto the skin. Gold and gemstone jewelry, a specialty of the ruined city of Manivarsha, is popular among wealthy citizens and often crafted by the descendants of artisans from the Manivarshi diaspora.

entries.name: Manivarshi Diaspora
entries: The city-state of Manivarsha was destroyed five hundred years ago under circumstances that have never fully been explained. On the last day of that year's Shankha Trials, the city simply vanished, along with everyone there. A few survivors who were just outside the city at the time told of a towering wave along the Adirohit River that marked its demise; subsequent attempts to reach its former location found nothing but endless swamps. Citizens who were away from home were left stranded. Those survivors and their descendants assimilated into the other cities, bringing Manivarsha's traditions of gem-cutting and jewel-setting to their new homes. This jewelry is now common throughout the land, and many pieces are fantastically valuable.

entries.name: Power and Politics
entries: Aside from their cultural rivalries, Sagorpur, Tippurika and Ashwadhatu rarely engage in major conflicts—living in a land that constantly changes with the caprices of the riverines is precarious enough. The shadow of the lost city of Manivarsha hangs over the remaining cities as a reminder that life in Shankhabhumi can easily be swept away.

Power in each city is shared between three factions—fifteen senators who officially govern the affairs of the city-state; a network of river-navigator majhis known as the Bhatiyali; and former Shankha Trials contestants who become famous public entertainers and heroes, if they don't become senators themselves.

entries.name: River Bounty
entries: Every meal in Shankhabhumi includes fish, though each city proclaims its own style of preparing it to be the best. In fact, cooking is a competitive discipline at the Shankha Trials. Sagorpuri fish curries are fragrant with spices imported from foreign lands, while Ashwadhatuj cook their fish with locally farmed vegetables, and Tippuris ferment their mountain fish in tea.

entries.name: Sign of the Shankha
entries: The shell of the conch mollusk, known locally as a shankha, is the eponymous icon of Shankhabhumi. The sizable Riverine's Shankha is the legendary shell trophy that circulates among the cities via the Shankha Trials, kept at the riverine temple in the current champion's city until that city hosts the next trials. Smaller shankhas are rare and precious, and they are often worn like pendants by those who can afford them. Shankha motifs decorate all riverine temples and adorn weaving, white-clay body art, jewelry, children's toys, pastries, and more.

entries.name: Names
entries: The given names of people in Shankhabhumi tend to be many syllables long and indicate the bearer's gender. Most folk use a last name based on their city of birth—Sagorpuri, Ashwadhatuj or Tippuri. The only exceptions are the descendants of Manivarsha (many of whom still use "Manivarshi") and majhis who take the last name "Bhatiyali." The following are common names in Shankhabhumi:

items.name: Feminine
items.entry: Amrapali, Bhanumati, Jamdani, Phullora

items.name: Masculine
items.entry: Anuttom, Chakrayudh, Rudrashekhar, Udayaditya

items.name: Gender-Neutral
items.entry: Kheya, Kobi, Palki, Ulka

entries.name: Legends of Shankhabhumi
entries: The ancestors of the people of Shankhabhumi migrated here from other lands about a thousand years ago. They arrived to find swamp forests infested with monsters and other dangers—a land shaped by hundreds of riverines who were indifferent to the newcomers and their fates. Then the elven leader Kubjhatika killed a giant mollusk that attacked her people. After the battle, she carved the tale of her victory and her people's journey on a beautiful, red-ridged shell. This shell became the Riverine's Shankha. Kubjhatika offered it as tribute to the riverines, appealing to them for refuge amid the unforgiving land.

The four greatest riverines—Adirohit, Iravati, Mehul, and Joltara—each wished to claim the Riverine's Shankha as their own. Kubjhatika proposed the Shankha Trials to ensure it would circulate fairly. But since people who could barely survive in this unstable land couldn't put on such a spectacular event, Kubjhatika persuaded the riverines to each create a site for a great city. Thus, the riverines created the stable islands on which Manivarsha, Sagorpur, Ashwadhatu, and Tippurika would be built, and the histories of those great cities began.

entries.name: Adventures in Shankhabhumi
entries: Consider the plots on the Shankhabhumi Adventures table when planning adventures in Shankhabhumi.

entries.caption: Shankhabhumi Adventures
rows: A den of {@creature Cultist||cultists} high in the Adhameru Mountains worships a {@creature spirit naga} and seeks to poison the riverine Joltara.

A Sagorpuri merchant has imprisoned a {@creature marid} within a shankha and intends to use its powers to help create a new city—potentially creating conflict with the riverines of the existing city-states.

A hermit asks for help when a newly born {@creature riverine|JttRC} (detailed at the {@area end of this adventure|2e2|x}) appears in a stream near her home. The hermit fears the aggressive riverine of a nearby river will see the young spirit as a rival and harm it.
Dense swamp trees grow overnight among a city-state's farmlands. Thousands of acres of thriving agricultural land will decay unless the magic that spawned the forest is identified and destroyed.

entries.name: Characters from Shankhabhumi
entries: If players create characters from Shankhabhumi, consider asking them the following questions during character creation:
{@b Which city do you come from?} Were you raised in cosmopolitan Sagorpur, traditionalist Ashwadhatu, or hardy Tippurika?

{@b Are you looking forward to the next Shankha Trials}? Are the trials the best part of living in Shankhabhumi for you, or just a spectacular nuisance every twelve years? Have you participated in past trials?
{@b Have you ever encountered a riverine?} Did the unpredictable spirit harm you or bless you in some way? Have you seen the riverine since then? Do you now have a deeper connection to it?

entries.name: Riverine
entries: More than mere waterway guardians, riverines are embodiments of particular rivers. These spirits of nature take shape to defend their waters and interact with those who travel along their currents. From the waist up, riverines have skin the color of the waters they protect but are otherwise humanlike in appearance. From the waist down, they can manifest either humanlike legs or churning gouts of water. A riverine's personality reflects the nature of the river it arises from—some are lethargic while others are wild and reckless.

entries.name: A Riverine's Lair
entries: Some riverines enjoy reverence akin to worship. Their likenesses are cast as statues and housed in temples, and worshipers act as agents between the river spirits and the people who revere them. These temples often become the home of the riverine itself, serving as its lair, though other nexuses of power along the river's path—such as its source or a significant waterfall—can also be used as lairs by a riverine.
A riverine encountered in its lair has a challenge rating of 13 (10,000 XP).

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the riverine can take one of the following lair actions; the riverine can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Phantasmal Mist
items.entry: The riverine creates fog around a creature it can see within 120 feet of it. The target must succeed on a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw or take 5 ({@dice 1d10}) psychic damage and be {@condition frightened} of the riverine until the end of the target's next turn.

items.name: River's Fury
items.entry: The riverine conjures swampy ground that briefly covers the ground in a 20-foot square the riverine can see within 120 feet of itself. That area becomes {@book difficult terrain|PHB|8|Difficult Terrain} until initiative count 20 on the next round. Any creature, other than the riverine, that enters the affected area or starts its turn there takes 7 ({@dice 2d6}) cold damage.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a riverine's lair flourishes under the magic of the riverine's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Clearwater Sight
items.entry: The waters of the river serve as a conduit for the riverine's consciousness. As an action, the riverine can cast the {@spell clairvoyance} spell, requiring no spell components, targeting any point along the river it's connected to.

items.name: River's Bounty
items.entry: Freshwater fauna and flora reproduce rapidly and thrive in the waters within 1 mile of the riverine's lair. Foraging in these waters yields twice the usual amount of food.

items.name: Spirit Guidance
items.entry: Tracks appear along the banks of the river within 6 miles of the riverine's lair. The tracks lead to potential shelters and safe passages across the river's waters, while also leading away from areas that the riverine prefers to remain undisturbed.

entries: If the riverine dies, the flora and fauna return to normal levels, and its river dries out over the course of {@dice 1d10} days. All other effects cease immediately.

data.name: Between Tangled Roots
entries: {@i An Adventure for 10th-Level Characters}

When a legendary dragon known as a {@creature bakunawa|JttRC} appears and attacks a town that has long revered its kind, the characters are called upon to learn why it has gone on a rampage. They must track down the bakunawa and discover the reason for its ire before dragon hunters slay the sacred creature.

entries.name: Background
entries: The bakunawa known as Pangil ng Buwan has long dwelled on the dangerous island of Lambakluha, once the holiest site on the Dayawlongon archipelago. Its dwelling lies before the great tree-temple called Bathalang Puno, a massive, mighty, sacred tree that was long ago burned by invaders. In the years that followed the tree's desecration, evil spirits infested the island. These foul spirits caused unnatural growths to manifest—spirit blisters that corrupt the land and its creatures. Gradually, this sickness encroached on Pangil ng Buwan's lair. While the ancient bakunawa slept, strangling roots enveloped it and poured poison into its being for centuries.

When Pangil ng Buwan awoke not long ago, its corruption caused it to hate all it once loved. After raging across Lambakluha, it sought its ancient spirit companion, Lungtian. But its one-time feelings of companionship has turned to rage, and it wreaks vast destruction in its search.

entries.name: Pronunciation Guide
entries: The Dayawlongon Pronunciations table details how to pronounce key names in this adventure.

entries.name: Setting the Adventure
entries: This adventure and the islands of the Dayawlongon archipelago can appear in any setting. The following are suggestions for contextualizing the adventure in a wider world:

items.name: Through the Radiant Citadel
items.entry: Characters traveling from the Radiant Citadel arrive in Dayawlongon near the town of Kalapang. While this adventure visits just two of the local islands, the "{@area Dayawlongon Gazetteer|328|x}" section provides context for further adventures you might have in the region.

items.name: Eberron
items.entry: The eastern coast of Sarlona or the seas around Aerenal could incorporate the Dayawlongon archipelago, or the islands could be in a new chain convenient to your other adventures.

items.name: Forgotten Realms
items.entry: Various islands in the Sea of Swords, such as those off the coast of Tethyr, could host the adventure's locations. The Dayawlongon archipelago could also be in the Sea of Fallen Stars, the Shining Sea, or elsewhere.

entries.name: Character Hooks
entries: Considérez les moyens suivants pour impliquer les personnages dans cette aventure :

items.name: Call of the Storyteller
items.entry: Via a mutual connection, the characters receive a plea to come to Kalapang from a binukot, a regional bard who serves as a repository of Dayawlongon's history. This performer, Nimuel, seeks the help of experienced adventurers for a delicate mission with a handsome reward.

items.name: Monster Hunt
items.entry: The characters hear rumors of a monster rampaging across the Dayawlongon archipelago. But soon after they arrive in the region, they receive word that the binukot Nimuel seeks a word with them, as not all is what it seems.

items.name: Rare Sighting
items.entry: A scholar friend of the characters has heard that a bakunawa, an exceptionally rare type of dragon, has appeared on the Dayawlongon archipelago. They entreat the characters to go and fetch a scale from the creature. To start the characters' quest, the scholar points them toward a local expert, Nimuel, in the town of Kalapang.

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries.title: The Storyteller Nimuel reveals the chaos caused by a rampaging bakunawa

entries: The adventure begins as the characters approach Kalapang. As they draw near, they witness a calamity. Read or paraphrase the following text to set the scene:
The trip to Kalapang has been uneventful, with travelers and trade wagons regularly passing. Soon the pale, vine-covered wall surrounding the town appears in the distance.

Suddenly, from the clear sky crackles a bolt of lightning followed by a thunderous screech. Above the town circles a mighty draconic form—an iridescent creature wreathed in lightning and with multiple sets of wings. As smoke begins to rise from Kalapang, the creature dives toward the town.

The characters are still a mile from Kalapang when Pangil ng Buwan—a {@creature bakunawa|JttRC} (see the {@area end of this adventure|337|x})—attacks. The attack is swift; the creature strafes the town, vanishes among the buildings for an instant, then soars away to the northwest. No matter what methods the characters use to reach Kalapang, the bakunawa has already departed by the time they reach town.
As the characters near Kalapang, they see people fetching water to put out fires and others tending to the wounded and scared. A character who asks these people what happened learns the following:

items: A bakunawa came out of nowhere and attacked. Its lightning breath and brief rampage caused terror, fires, and ruin.
A bakunawa is a kind of dragon said to hold power over the seas and skies.
Dayawlongon was once protected by gigantic bakunawa, but they vanished long ago. Their smaller descendants are rare.
Bakunawa are sacred in the region, though dragon hunters pursue rumors of them, hoping to sell their body parts for gold or as sacred relics.

entries: Characters who help the locals are thanked, but the locals largely have the situation under control. The characters are allowed to enter the walled town unimpeded.

entries.name: Destruction in Kalapang
entries: As the characters enter Kalapang, read or paraphrase the following:

The streets of Kalapang are filled with rushing people, some trying to douse smoldering rooftops, others tending to the wounded or to crying youngsters. Nearby, a row of homes lies in rubble. Iridescent blue scales are scattered amid the debris.

A woman wearing a teal dress embroidered with golden constellations surveys the destruction. She waves in your direction, then approaches. "You arrived at a difficult time. I'd hoped to prevent exactly this," she says, gesturing at the fallen building. "I am Nimuel. Thank you for answering my call." The woman pauses, looking around at the chaos, before addressing you again. "Follow me. I know a place where we won't have to worry about others overhearing—and there's someone I need you to meet."

Before the characters can go with Nimuel, the character who has the highest passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score notices something moving amid the debris. A character who investigates realizes someone's trapped in the rubble. Clearing the rubble safely requires a character to make a DC 14 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. On a failed check, they find one of the home's residents (a {@creature commoner}) {@condition unconscious} with 0 hit points. On a successful check, they find the resident coughing but largely unharmed. Whether found conscious or restored by healing, the resident thanks the characters. The resident can't reward the characters but speaks well of them to the whole neighborhood—a development that impresses Nimuel.

entries.name: The Spirit and the Storyteller
entries: Following the rescue, Nimuel asks the characters to follow her to a quiet, nearby courtyard shaded by an ancient salingbobog tree. When the group arrives, a figure steps from the base of the tree. This is Lungtian, a ninuno and Nimuel's partner. Light clothing of leaves and vines grows from Lungtian's body, and when Lungtian speaks, their voice sounds like rustling leaves. A character who succeeds on a DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill History}) or Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check knows that a ninuno is a spirit of the land, similar to a dryad, who serves as an intermediary between the living and the gods. Nimuel or Lungtian shares these details if asked, along with any specifics from the "{@area Life in Dayawlongon|32e|x}" section later in this adventure.

entries.name: Nimuel
entries: Nimuel (neutral good, human {@creature mage}) is a binukot in Kalapang, a scholar who collects and orally shares the region's wisdom, laws, traditions, culture, songs, poetry, literature, and more. Though young, she is so distinguished that many come to her for guidance and for stewarding their own stories.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: "I seek to honor the gods with every song I sing and every word I speak."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "The history of our land is rich with wonders and missteps. By sharing these truths, I can help create a greater future."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "My tie to Lungtian is special and brings me closer to the divine."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I would never question the will of the gods or their servants."

entries.name: Lungtian
entries: The ninuno Lungtian (chaotic good {@creature dryad}) was once a human and one of the first binukots of Kalapang. In this earlier life, they fought to defend the land from invaders alongside Pangil ng Buwan and formed a deep friendship with the bakunawa. When Lungtian died, the gods brought their spirit back as a dryad-like ninuno.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: "I am devoted to whoever protects the land and its people."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "The land and its ways must be defended, most of all those ancient beings—like bakunawa—who created all that exists today."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "My love for Nimuel makes me feel like my old self."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I compare all mortals I meet to the heroes I've known throughout my long life."

entries.name: The Bakunawa's Wrath
entries: Nimuel introduces Lungtian, then moves on to explain that the message she sent the characters arose from the ninuno's concern. The two share the following information:

items: The bakunawa that attacked Kalapang is named Pangil ng Buwan, and it is one of the oldest of its kind. It fought against foreign invaders long ago and has never been hostile toward the land's people.
Pangil ng Buwan was a friend to Lungtian, but the bakunawa disappeared more than two hundred years ago.

A few weeks ago, Lungtian began having visions of corruption centered on the island of Lambakluha, once a holy place and now a ruined land. Pangil ng Buwan appeared in these visions, leaving Lungtian to believe the bakunawa still lives.
Lungtian and Nimuel ask the characters to seek out Pangil ng Buwan, discover what's happened to it, and bring it peace.
Nimuel offers the characters 600 gp apiece as a reward, while Lungtian promises them a divine blessing (see "{@area Ninuno's Mark|327|x}" in the adventure's conclusion).

entries: Additionally, Nimuel and Lungtian can share any information from the "{@area Dayawlongon Gazetteer|328|x}" section later in this adventure. Before the conversation ends, Lungtian shares one more important piece of information:

"During the attack, I could feel Pangil ng Buwan," Lungtian whispers. "There was a shadow in its spirit. Something poisonous and pulsing, a sickness I don't know. The bakunawa seemed to be fighting with itself. I believe that's why we've seen many injured but no dead among the rubble."

Lungtian glances toward the street, still packed with wounded and scared people, then continues. "I want you to know and understand this—after today, I don't expect many to have the ears to hear such things."

entries.name: Mission to Lambakluha
entries: If the characters agree to Nimuel and Lungtian's terms, Lungtian tells the characters that Pangil ng Buwan's home was once the island of Lambakluha. The pair originally wanted the characters to journey to the island and discover the source of Lungtian's visions along with any signs of Pangil ng Buwan. Now, this mission is even more urgent—the bakunawa must be found and calmed.

A sea voyage to Lambakluha would be perilous due to the raging whirlpools that separate the archipelago's islands, but the characters can reach Lambakluha in an easy two-day journey by traversing Flames Everlasting, one of the skybridges that connect the islands. This skybridge stretches from the island of Malabulak to Lambakluha, where Pangil ng Buwan once made its home in Bathalang Puno, a massive holy tree killed long ago. The island is largely deserted, but at the end of Flames Everlasting is a camp called the Final Steps of Courage, home to soldiers and scholars seeking to fight back the dangers infesting the island.

entries.name: Preparations in Kalapang
entries: Although Nimuel and Lungtian encourage the characters to depart for Lambakluha as swiftly as possible, the party can rest and resupply in Kalapang as long as the characters need. Pangil ng Buwan doesn't threaten the town again during this time.

Characters who explore the town find the people hospitable but distracted, fearing that the bakunawa might return at any moment. Most shops are closed, but the characters can find shops selling {@book any item|PHB|4} from the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. A local inn called the Root and Roost offers rooms for 1 gp a night. The price normally includes a hot meal, but with everything going on, the kitchen offers only a cold meal of mangoes and shrimp paste.

entries.name: Traveling the Skybridge
entries: Journeying from Kalapang to the foot of the Flames Everlasting Skybridge takes only a few hours. Travel is quick along the main roads, and word of the attack on Kalapang has spread to the few travelers the party meets. Most people are headed away from Kalapang, believing the bakunawa will return.
As the characters near the skybridge, read the following description:

A magnificent bridge arcs into the air, stretching high above the trees and over the sea beyond. The span soars without supports, its path bending in serpentine curves that stretch into the distance. The bridge is over a hundred feet wide, and statues of stern, draconic creatures adorn it.

Flames Everlasting is typical of the skybridges that connect the islands of the Dayawlongon archipelago, though it's used less than the others. These legendary structures were created by draconic magic in the distant past and still feature prominently in local legends. Characters who succeed on a DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check know the details about skybridges from the "{@area Noteworthy Sites|32a|x}" section at the end of this adventure. Any travelers the characters pass are also happy to share these details.

entries.name: Dragon Hunters
entries: As the characters approach the foot of the skybridge, they find a group of five locals with horses resting and sharing a meal at the roadside. The five are well armed and look like hunters or adventurers. If the characters approach openly, the group's leader waves them over. When the characters are within earshot, the leader introduces himself as follows:

"Hail travelers! I'm Paolo Maykapal, and judging by your road, I guess that you've come from Kalapang. Tell me, were you there during the attack? Are the rumors true? If Pangil ng Buwan has returned, I swear by all my ancestors that the monster will die by my hand."

Paolo is the group's leader, and he travels with four of his cousins: Dolores, Raqua, Senedicto, and Yomas. They were raised together and share Paolo's conviction that they must slay the bakunawa as vengeance for wrongs done to their clan. All five {@creature Dragon Hunter|JttRC|dragon hunters} are lawful neutral humans. They use the {@creature veteran} stat block with the following adjustments:

items: They wear {@item studded leather armor|PHB} that gives them AC 13.
Replace the Heavy Crossbow action with the action below.

entries.name: Longbow
entries: Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, ranged 150/600 ft., one target. Hit: 5 ({@dice 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

entries.name: Paolo Maykapal
entries: One of the city of Laguna's finest heroes, Paolo Maykapal has trained his entire life to kill bakunawa. He is warm and friendly but is uncompromising when it comes to carrying out his work. Now that Pangil ng Buwan has returned, his duty to the memory of his clan's founder and ancestors is clear. He's willing to engage in underhanded behavior to ensure he and his team succeed.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: "Everything I do and say has a purpose. I've no time for frivolities."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I want to be a living example of a true Dayawlongo: one who gives everything for family and country."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "What I want matters less than what is good for my home."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I will use anyone who isn't part of my family as a means to an end."

entries.name: The Dragon Hunters' Offer
entries: Paolo and his group listen intently to anything the characters share and ask them about the bakunawa, what it looked like, and how it behaved. A character who succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check can tell Paolo is trying to learn all he can about the bakunawa but is less concerned about Kalapang or its people.
If the characters don't share details of their experience with Paolo, he still recognizes them as adventurers and asks them to join his group as they head to Lambakluha to slay Pangil ng Buwan.
Even if the characters don't join the dragon hunters, Paolo eagerly discusses any of the following points:

items: Pangil ng Buwan was seen flying away to the southwest. Paolo and his group plan to follow via the skybridge.

Paolo and his cousins hate Pangil ng Buwan due to the Maykapal Clan's blood feud with the bakunawa. During the region's last revolution against foreign aggression two hundred years ago, Pangil ng Buwan abandoned the defense of the city of Laguna. This resulted in the death of Urian, the founder of Laguna and the Maykapal Clan.

Generations of Laguna hunters have grown up on stories of Pangil ng Buwan's betrayal. When Paolo heard word of a bakunawa seen in the skies over Dayawlongon, he began to seek the creature so he can settle his clan's blood feud.
Paolo is also certain he and his group can make a profit from selling pieces of the bakunawa's corpse and would split the profits with the characters.

entries: To anyone who speaks out against hunting the bakunawa, Paolo laughs and says:
"Yes, yes. I hear those who speak of the monsters as though they're gods. But Pangil ng Buwan is a god who left my people, my city, the founder of my clan to die. Surely you understand my position?"

Nothing any character can say deters Paolo or his allies from their quest. If the characters decide to work with Paolo's group, the two groups travel to Lambakluha together. If the party chooses not to accompany Paolo and his group, Paolo politely wishes them safe travels but says nothing more of the dragon hunters' plans. His group then hangs back. They ultimately use {@item Necklace of Prayer Beads||necklaces of prayer beads} from a bonesinger ({@area see the following section|30c|x}) that they had previously aided to {@spell wind walk} to Lambakluha and reach Bathalang Puno about the same time as the characters.

entries.name: Traveling the Skybridge
entries: The journey across the Flames Everlasting Skybridge takes 36 hours, with the incredible bridge soaring 600 feet or more over forests, steep hills, and the sea. Like all the skybridges between the Dayawlongon islands, this bridge is well-lit by gentle magical light at night. It once featured way stations, but few travel to Lambakluha anymore, so the way stations are abandoned, and the party encounters few people during their travels. As the characters make their way to Lambakluha, roll on the Skybridge Sights table after every 12 hours of travel—or whenever you see fit—to determine what encounters they have.

entries.caption: Skybridge Sights
rows: A small storm reveals itself to be a violent group of three {@creature Air Elemental||air elementals}.
A dead wyvern lies on the skybridge, its body scorched by lightning.
A curious and friendly {@creature cloud giant} is surprised to see travelers on the skybridge and asks them at length about recent happenings in the lands below.

entries.title: Flames Everlasting Skybridge stretches over steep hills and seas to the island of Lambakluha

entries.name: Bonesinger
entries: As the characters travel the skybridge, they might encounter a lone old woman crouching near one of the draconic statues adorning the bridge, singing to it in a gentle voice. This is Ina (neutral good, human {@creature priest}), a skybridge tender known as a bonesinger. She tends the magic that supports and protects Flames Everlasting and honors the many gigantic, ancient bakunawa whose bones are infused into the bridge.

Ina greets the characters courteously and warns them of the dangers of Lambakluha. The bonesinger has not yet heard of the attack in Kalapang and is horrified if the characters share the news with her. If asked about recent bakunawa activity, Ina says she's heard a bakunawa's call over the skybridge in the night, but she has seen nothing.

After conversing with the characters, Ina returns to her ritual song and invites the characters to join in. Any character can sing with her, but those who do so and succeed on a DC 18 Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check impress the bonesinger. She thanks the first character to impress her by giving them her {@item necklace of prayer beads}. The necklace's beads look like tiny fangs and include a bead of {@spell wind walk} and {@dice 1d4} other magic beads.

entries.name: Sighting Lambakluha
entries: A few hours before the party reaches Lambakluha, the party spots their destination:
The mist on the horizon parts, revealing a gigantic tree thousands of feet tall, its highest branches hidden by clouds. The great tree's boughs are bent, barren, and lifeless.

A character who succeeds on a DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check knows this tree is Bathalang Puno, one of the holy trees of the Dayawlongon archipelago that was burned by invaders long ago. Soon after the characters sight the tree, the stench of ash permeates the air.

entries.name: Lambakluha
entries: Once a verdant island with an expansive network of rivers and mangrove forests, Lambakluha is now a rank swamp. Tormented spirits haunt the island, especially its ruined communities, and their corruptive influence blights the surviving life. The island can be reached by two skybridges: Flames Everlasting, which the characters traveled, and Hope's Dagger, which leads to another island to the west.
Lambakluha is depicted on map 10.1.

entries.name: The Final Steps of Courage
entries: As the characters pass the final bend of Flames Everlasting, read the following description of the skybridge's end:

The skybridge descends onto a sizable island overgrown with tangled swamp vegetation and covered in a haze tasting of ash. A few acres at the skybridge's end have been cleared and surrounded by a wooden palisade. Within, simple wooden buildings and dingy tents form an encampment.

The camp is called the Final Steps of Courage, and beyond it spreads the blighted landscape of Lambakluha. The skybridge ends within the redoubt's wooden walls, which hold tents for a few dozen soldiers and scholars, as well as a mess hall and trading post. The camp's amenities are for those working there, but if the characters distinguish themselves as the soldiers' allies or succeed on a DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check with mess hall or trading post staff, they can use the facilities, too.

Should the characters follow the skybridge into the camp, four sentries (use the {@creature veteran} stat block) armed with crossbows stop them and question them about their origins, business, and destination.

entries.name: Attack on the Final Steps
entries: As the characters converse with the sentries, a horn sounds from the camp's south gate. The sentries run toward the opposite side of the camp while the camp staff scatter. If the characters follow the sound, they see several tortured-looking incorporeal Undead attacking the camp's south gate and soldiers making an organized defense. A moment later, whether the characters are near the gate or elsewhere, three {@creature Wraith||wraiths} that look like the spirits of burn victims close in on the characters and attack.

entries.name: What the Soldiers Know
entries: If the characters defeat the wraiths, the camp's commander, Captain Atoy, thanks the characters and welcomes them to rest, eat, and resupply.

The soldiers and scholars of the camp are here in hopes of reclaiming Lambakluha and making it safe for resettlement. Their work is slow, as the tortured spirits of the land attack at random intervals. The soldiers are used to defending against spirits, but in recent weeks they've spotted flashes of blue lightning near Bathalang Puno, Pangil ng Buwan's storied lair.

If the characters explain to Captain Atoy or others in the camp that they're seeking Bathalang Puno and Pangil ng Buwan, the soldiers warn them of the danger, not just of the bakunawa but of the miles of swamp known as the Weeping Paths that the characters will have to traverse. If the characters ask anyone in the camp about what dangers they might face, the soldiers speak of Undead and of vicious vegetation.
